texts.shortText: Small, solitary and rarely sighted intertidal and shallow-water cephalopod with globular muscular mantle and head, no externally visible shell and eight contractile arms. Mantle surface with wrinkled skin and very small granules but otherwise smooth and without any larger papillae, cirri or tubercles. Each arm has about 60-80 suckers that are irregularly spaced. The genus Eledone is defined by a single row of suckers, however this species is an exception in having a non-uniform single to double zigzag row of suckers. Suckers on arm pairs 1-3 particularly enlarged around sucker numbers 6-10 (counted from the mouth). Right third arm hectocotylised, meaning it has a distinct spermatophoral groove along the side as well as a modified arm tip to deliver a sperm package to the female. All non-hectocoylised arm tips have bunches of long, sensory finger or brush-like projections instead of suckers (hence the name ‘brush-tip’). It is still unclear but possible that the brush-like arm structures only occur in males. Unable to change colour in the same way as other octopus species, and appearance is always uniformly red-brown and easy to identify.
Mantle length to 10 cm, total length to 50 cm, weight to 350 g.

Global distribution: Endemic to the west coast of southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to Table Bay in South Africa, 0-18 m.

Hardly any biological information exists for this probably solitary benthic species typically found in intertidal and shallow rocky reefs. Dens are undefined small holes between mussels and crevices and often found under larger rocks. Life expectancies of 1-2 years are estimates from other related species. The large and highly reflective eyes may suggest that the species could be majorly nocturnal. Probably more common than thought, but rarely seen due to its small size, secretive lifestyle, and since it lives along the highly wave-exposed west coast that can be difficult to access.

Speculative but probably feeds on small crustaceans, gastropods and bivalves in the intertidal and shallow subtidal areas. Very likely a favourite prey of the shysharks and catsharks, as well as of the Crowned cormorant, and especially of the much larger Common octopus. Predations and the ecological interactions with the latter are of special interest as they may restrict the distribution of the Brush-tip octopus to the cold west coast where the Common octopus is less abundant.

Sexes are separate and like in other octopus species the male uses the third right arm to pass on a spermatophore (sperm package) into the ovary of the female. Females probably create a den where they lay and guard their eggs, which then hatch and get released as paralava into the water column. There are no field observation of mating or reproduction of this species.

Difficult to confuse with the Common octopus Octopus vulgaris Type 3 due to its smaller size, the more bulbous head and mantle and the uniformly red-brown colour that does not change. The brush-like arm tips or the unusual sucker rows are highly distinctive but difficult to see in the wild or from photos.
